snippet: The details and names of nearly 5,000 people killed by the Afghan Communist government in 1978 and 1979 were unearthed by Dutch investigators and made public by the Netherlands national prosecutor’s office.
abstract: Details and names of nearly 5,000 Afghans arrested, tortured and killed by the Afghan Communist government in 1978 and 1979 have resurfaced, cataloged in records released in September; release of so-called death lists have galvanized Afghan public; government's reaction to the lists was initially cautious, with Pres Hamid Karzai quoted as saying that reconciliation is more important than prosecutions.

byline.contributor: Sharifullah Sahak and Jawad Sukhanyar contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: The details and names of nearly 5,000 people killed by the Afghan Communist government in 1978 and 1979 were unearthed by Dutch investigators and made public by the Netherlands national prosecutor’s office.

headline.main: Old Atrocities, Now Official, Galvanize Afghanistan
